DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls Slaying an `Outrage,' Weighs Response
Eds: Inserts 1 graf with Monday incident after 10th graf pvs, During four; inserts 2 grafs reaction after 14th graf pvs, He said
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Monday the killing of an American serviceman in Panama was ``an enormous outrage'' and that the United States was considering options to deal with Manuel Antonio Noriega. Bush did not rule out military steps. ``I think a president, all presidents, have options, but they don't discuss what they might be,'' Bush said in an interview. He repeated that answer when asked if military options were being reviewed. Questioned about Noriega's declaration of a ``state of war'' between Panama and the United States, Bush said, ``I've taken note of his statement.'' A high-level interagency group met at the State Department to discuss options on Panama, said sources who requested anonymity. The United States has been trying to force Noriega's ouster since his indictment in Florida on drug-smuggling charges in February 1988. The United States supported an unsuccessful coup attempt against Noriega Oct. 3. On Friday, Noriega declared a state of war with the United States and had himself installed by the national assembly as the country's supreme leader. The next day, violence flared when four American officers, traveling unarmed, in civilian clothes and in a private car, were trying to flee a crowd of Panamanian troops and civilians after the car had been stopped at a Panamanian roadblock, the Pentagon said. One serviceman was killed when the Panamanian soldiers opened fire. Another U.S. officer's ankle was grazed by a bullet. After the shooting, the Panamanians arrested a U.S. Navy lieutenant and his wife who had been stopped earlier at the roadblock. During four hours of interrogation, the Pentagon said, that officer was repeatedly beaten and kicked in the groin and his wife was sexually thratened and slammed against a wall. Another incident occurred Monday, when an American officer shot and wounded a Panamanian corporal near a U.S. installation, a Southern Command official said. The official said the U.S. officer believed the Panamanian was drawing his weapon and felt threatened. Bush, in an interview with The Associated Press and three other news agencies, said, ``One of the frustrations that I've had during this year is the whole Panama situation, an enormous frustration.'' Asked how the United States would respond to the officer's death, Bush said, ``It's an enormous outrage and a matter of enormous concern to this president.'' As for the steps available to him, Bush said, ``For one, I can tell you how strongly I feel about it, which I've just done, and two, review whatever options might be available, and three, not discuss what they might be.'' He said he wanted to have a free hand ``without having positioned myself on what it is I want to do.'' Meanwhile, Rep. Ike Skelton, D-Mo. a member of the House Armed Services Committee, said the United States ``can't put up with Noriega's actions'' and will have to take steps to stop the arrests, detentions, beatings and harassment of U.S. forces. ``The question is how do we do it,'' Skelton said. ``Do we wait for the PDF (Panamanian Defense Forces) to stage another coup or do we take another step'' of unilateral military action. Bush and his predecessor, former President Reagan, have hinted at military action against Noriega but have refrained from a direct assault. Meanwhile, White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the United States was ``very concerned'' about Noriega's declaration of war. He said it ``may have been a license for harassment and threats and in this case murder.'' Fitzwater said most U.S. dependents have left Panama or have been moved onto the U.S. military base there. He said that a 9:50 p.m. curfew had been imposed over the weekend on U.S. military personnel and that the base was on a high state of alert. ``There's no question that it's a dangerous situation,'' Fitzwater said. He said the mistreatment of the naval officer's wife ``certainly goes beyond any previous experience. And the murder is outrageous in itself.'' The United States has 12,000 troops stationed in Panama.
